subject: Technology
title: GPS: How Your Phone Knows Where You Are
description: A quick, practical guide to GPS: How Your Phone Knows Where You Are.

hook.text: Your phone can pinpoint your location within a few meters. It does this by talking to satellites in space.

buildup.text: GPS uses a constellation of 31 satellites orbiting Earth. Your phone listens to signals from at least four.

discovery.text: Each satellite broadcasts its position and exact time. Your phone calculates distance by measuring signal delay.

twist.text: GPS was built by the U.S. military. It was opened to civilians after a Korean airliner was shot down in 1983.

climax.text: Today GPS powers navigation, ride-sharing, delivery tracking, and even farming equipment.

punchline.text: Military satellites guide your pizza delivery.

quiz.question: How many satellites does GPS use to determine location?
